description: Borrowed from French concours, from Latin concursus, from concurrere (“to run together”). See concur.

entries.meaning: A large open space in or in front of a building where people can gather, particularly one joining various paths, as in a rail station or airport terminal, or providing access to and linking the platforms in a railway terminus.
examples: In east London in October 2013, during a game between West Ham and Manchester City, a small group of home Muslim fans - with no prayer room available - tried to offer their Maghrib (sunset) prayer on a concourse under the main stand at the club's former home Upton Park.

entries.meaning: A large group of people; a crowd.
examples: Amidst the concourse were to be seen the noble ladies of Milan, in gay, fantastic cars, shining in silk brocade.

entries.meaning: The running or flowing together of things; the meeting of things; confluence.
examples: ... there was only wanting the concourse of rains ...

entries.meaning: An open space, especially in a park, where several roads or paths meet.
